# Comprehensive Functional Analysis of Gene Programs in Astrocytoma: A Literature-Based Investigation

Astrocytoma represents a spectrum of glial tumors arising from astrocytes, with molecular subtypes increasingly recognized as critical determinants of clinical behavior and therapeutic response[4]. The molecular classification of astrocytomas has evolved substantially through genomic studies, distinguishing IDH-mutant astrocytomas with relatively favorable prognoses from IDH wild-type variants that demonstrate aggressive behavior[4]. This analysis examines 169 genes within the context of astrocytoma biology, integrating evidence from recent multiomic studies, mechanistic investigations, and functional characterizations to identify coherent gene programs that operate in this malignant transformation. The identified programs span cellular adhesion reorganization, extracellular matrix remodeling, signal transduction cascades, cytoskeletal dynamics, reactive glial activation, metabolic reprogramming, transcriptional control, and immune modulation—each representing distinct but interconnected facets of astrocytoma pathobiology.

## Extracellular Matrix Remodeling and Stromal Interactions in Astrocytoma Invasion

The extracellular matrix within glioblastomas and astrocytomas constitutes a dynamic microenvironment that fundamentally influences tumor cell behavior[53]. Recent single-cell spatial transcriptomic analysis of glioblastoma matrisomal components reveals that distinct tumor cell populations express unique combinations of ECM genes, with spatial enrichment patterns that correlate with intratumoral architecture and cellular function[53]. The genes POSTN (periostin), EFEMP1, ADAMTS9, and related proteolytic enzymes represent a coordinated program mediating matrix remodeling essential for tumor invasion and stromal reorganization. Periostin, encoded by POSTN, is a matricellular protein secreted by stromal cells including fibroblasts and myofibroblasts within glioblastoma microenvironments[7]. This protein functions not merely as a structural component but as a signaling molecule that activates integrin-dependent pathways in adjacent tumor cells and stroma-resident cells. ADAMTS9 and its antisense transcript ADAMTS9-AS1 represent secreted proteoglycans and proteases that actively remodel the collagen-rich matrix surrounding astrocytomas, facilitating cell migration and vascular infiltration[2].

The spatial transcriptomic data from glioblastoma tissues identifies ECM ligand-receptor networks between tumor cells and stromal populations, revealing that vascular endothelial cells and microglia/macrophages express complementary patterns of ECM components and receptor genes[53]. Integrin-mediated adhesion to matrix components represents a critical axis controlling astrocytoma cell behavior. The genes ITGA3, ITGA5, and ITGAV encode integrin alpha subunits that associate with beta-1 integrin (ITGB1, not explicitly in list but functionally coupled) to form heterodimeric receptors for fibronectin, collagen, and other matrix ligands[37]. These integrins promote tumor invasion through both transcriptional reprogramming and direct mechanotransduction pathways. Integrin signaling through focal adhesion complexes, involving PTK2B (Pyk2), SHC1, and downstream kinases, activates phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase and mitogen-activated protein kinase cascades that drive proliferation and motility[16][19]. The matrix metalloproteinase TIMP1 and related tissue inhibitors function reciprocally to suppress excessive ECM degradation while permitting controlled invasion[11].

Laminin-binding interactions mediated through LAMB1 provide additional matrix-contact dependent signaling that regulates astrocytoma cell state[37]. The spatial organization of these ECM-rich compartments within glioblastoma lesions reflects both tumor-autonomous expression and recruitment of stromal fibroblasts expressing collagens and proteoglycans[53]. This ECM program appears particularly prominent in regions surrounding neovascular beds and at the infiltrative margin of tumors, where ECM remodeling facilitates transition into normal brain parenchyma. The expression of secreted phosphoprotein 1 (SPP1, also called osteopontin) by tumor and stromal cells further promotes cell adhesion and migration while simultaneously engaging immune signaling through integrins and CD44[35]. Collectively, this program represents coordinated matrix remodeling that simultaneously supports structural integrity of the tumor microenvironment while enabling invasive phenotypes—a critical balance in astrocytoma aggressiveness.

## Signal Transduction Networks Controlling Growth and Survival

Astrocytomas, particularly IDH wild-type glioblastomas, rely upon constitutive activation of receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathways that promote cell proliferation and suppress differentiation[4]. Multiple genes within the input list encode scaffolding proteins, adapter molecules, and kinases that participate in these cascades. The receptor tyrosine kinase KDR (VEGF receptor 2) represents a primary node in vascular endothelial growth factor signaling, critical for both neoangiogenesis and direct tumor cell survival[20][21]. KDR activation recruits neuropilins NRP1 and NRP2 as co-receptors, enhancing ligand binding and signal propagation[38][41]. The membrane protein EFNB2 (ephrin-B2) engages in bidirectional signaling with Eph receptors, contributing to vascular development and potentially to astrocytoma cell positioning within the microenvironment[21].

Downstream of receptor activation, the adapter protein SHC1 couples receptor autophosphorylation to the GRB10-RAS pathway and related mitogenic cascades[44]. Protein tyrosine kinase 2 beta (PTK2B, also called Pyk2) and focal adhesion kinase (FAK, PTK2, not explicitly listed but functionally coupled) mediate integrin-dependent signaling that converges with growth factor pathways to regulate migration and invasion[16][19]. These kinases phosphorylate downstream effectors including RAC1, which functions as a Rho family GTPase regulating actin dynamics and cell motility. The guanine nucleotide exchange factors ARHGEF3, TRIO, and related regulators modulate RAC1 and RHO activation states, collectively orchestrating cellular architecture and movement[15][18]. TRIO specifically demonstrates elevated expression in glioblastomas versus lower-grade gliomas and contributes substantially to tumor cell migration[15].

The phosphatase PTPRE and related protein tyrosine phosphatases provide negative feedback within these signaling networks, with PTPRE potentially limiting kinase activation. GRB10 (growth factor receptor bound protein 10) functions as an adaptor that can either promote or suppress signaling depending on context and phosphorylation state[44]. The ERC2 protein (ELKS/rab6-interacting/CAST family member 2) organizes signaling complexes at active zones, potentially scaffolding kinase cascades. This signal transduction program represents a fundamental requirement for astrocytoma growth and represents a major target of current therapeutic interventions using kinase inhibitors. The downstream activation of both proliferation and survival signals through these pathways becomes particularly important in IDH wild-type glioblastomas, which lack the relatively favorable prognosis associated with IDH mutations[4].

## Cytoskeletal Reorganization and Cell Motility Processes

The remarkable invasive capacity of astrocytomas reflects sophisticated reorganization of the actin and microtubule cytoskeleton. Multiple genes within the input set encode proteins that directly regulate these structures or transduce environmental cues into cytoskeletal rearrangement. Microtubule-associated proteins (particularly MAP1B) regulate the architecture and dynamics of microtubule networks essential for establishing cell polarity, axonal transport, and cell migration[51]. MAP1B functions in concert with other microtubule plus-end tracking proteins and minus-end anchoring complexes to establish directional cell migration. The growth-associated protein GAP43, historically known as a neuronal growth cone marker, participates in local actin polymerization and membrane dynamics particularly at leading edges[15].

Actin regulatory proteins constitute a substantial portion of this program. DNMBP (dynamin-binding protein, also called tuba) functions as a nucleation promoter factor that influences actin polymerization through interactions with Arp2/3 complex components[51]. KALRN encodes kalirin, a guanine nucleotide exchange factor for Rho family GTPases (particularly RAC1 and CDC42) that drives spine formation and cell motility through localized actin polymerization[15]. FBLIM1 (filamin binding LIM protein 1) acts as an adapter linking actin networks to signaling pathways and focal adhesions[15]. PDLIM7 (PDZ and LIM domain 7) similarly organizes protein complexes at specialized membrane domains where actin dynamics are locally regulated[15].

The formin PRRX1 and related actin nucleation factors promote linear actin polymerization, generating distinct actin structures compared to the branched networks generated by Arp2/3 complex[15]. NEBL (nebulette) functions as an Z-disk associated protein in muscle but may play analogous roles in organizing actin networks in non-muscle cells[15]. MYOF (myoferlin) and MYRFL (myoferlin-like) regulate membrane trafficking and fusion events that support localized membrane expansion during cell motility. The phospholipase PLCH1 generates inositol lipid second messengers that activate downstream calcium signaling and actin dynamics[15]. Collectively, these cytoskeletal regulators enable the transition from polygonal tumor cells to migratory spindle morphologies characteristic of infiltrative astrocytomas, particularly important for tumor cells navigating through brain parenchyma.

## Adhesive Interactions and Cell-Cell Contact Regulation

Astrocytomas exhibit profound alterations in cell-cell adhesive properties compared to normal astrocytes, enabling both loss of contact inhibition and capacity for individual cell migration. The cadherin superfamily of adhesion molecules regulates these transitions. CDH2 (N-cadherin) represents a prototypical calcium-dependent adhesion molecule expressed at high levels in astrocytomas and tumor-derived glioma stem cells[4]. Unlike CDH1 (E-cadherin), which mediates epithelial adhesion and often suppresses invasion, CDH2 permits more dynamic cell-cell contacts compatible with collective migration and individual invasion. Astrocytomas expressing elevated CDH2 levels demonstrate enhanced migratory capacity, reflecting N-cadherin's role in regulating dynamic adhesion properties rather than establishing stable epithelial barriers.

The contactin family proteins (CNTNAP3, CNTNAP3B, NRCAM) mediate homophilic and heterophilic cell-cell interactions through immunoglobulin and fibronectin-type repeats[15][58]. These proteins participate in neural cell adhesion networks and may influence astrocytoma cell recognition and organization within the tumor mass. Neurofascin (NFASC), another member of the L1 family of immunoglobulin cell adhesion molecules, mediates homophilic interactions and couples to cytoskeletal anchoring proteins including ankyrin and spectrin complexes. The functional conservation of these adhesion molecules across astrocytes and astrocytomas suggests that tumor cells retain developmental programs governing cell-cell recognition, albeit often dysregulated through altered expression levels or post-translational modifications.

Placental cadherin-related (PDPN, also called podoplanin) represents another adhesion molecule altered in astrocytomas, with expression patterns reflecting tumor cell differentiation state and potentially predicting prognosis[56]. PODXL (podocalyxin-like), another mucin-type sialoglycoprotein, regulates cell-cell adhesion through effects on surface electrostatics and receptor clustering. These adhesion molecules collectively determine the architectural organization of astrocytoma masses and the cell biological properties enabling transition between collective invasion and individual cell dissemination. The dynamic regulation of these adhesive properties through expression level changes and post-translational modifications represents a key mechanism by which astrocytomas acquire phenotypic flexibility during tumor progression.

## Reactive Astrocyte Activation Programs and Glial Responses to Tumor Microenvironment

While the focus of this analysis concerns tumor astrocytes rather than reactive normal astrocytes, understanding the reactive astrocyte transcriptional program provides essential context for interpreting astrocytoma gene expression patterns[57]. Recent studies on injury-responsive enhancers in glial cells reveal that reactive astrocytes upregulate a stereotyped program of genes controlling immune interactions, barrier formation, and wound response[57]. Several genes within the input list demonstrate patterns of expression consistent with reactive astrocyte activation, including CHI3L1 (chitinase 3-like 1, also called YKL-40), SERPINE1 (plasminogen activator inhibitor 1), and others.

CHI3L1 encodes a secreted glycoprotein with limited enzymatic chitinase activity but substantial immune modulatory functions[23]. This protein appears upregulated in both reactive astrocytes and in gliomas, where it may reflect partial capture of the normal reactive astrocyte program by tumor cells[23]. SERPINE1 represents a serpin superfamily member that inhibits tissue plasminogen activator and urokinase plasminogen activator, thereby suppressing extracellular matrix degradation and likely contributing to ECM stability[12]. Elevated SERPINE1 in gliomas associates with altered immune infiltration patterns and correlates with poorer survival[10]. The expression of immune-related genes including IL1R1 (interleukin-1 receptor type 1) and genes encoding chemokine signaling components suggests that tumor astrocytes maintain inflammatory response capacity while simultaneously sculpting the immune microenvironment[36].

The transcriptional control of these reactive programs involves multiple transcription factors, several represented in the input list. STAT1 (signal transducer and activator of transcription 1) mediates interferon-gamma signaling and represents a classical marker of immune activation in both normal and tumor astrocytes[22][25]. The related molecule NOS1AP (NOS1 adaptor protein) functions in nitric oxide synthesis and associated signaling[73]. These reactive programs likely reflect both retained developmental programming in tumor astrocytes and active responses to microenvironmental cytokines produced by infiltrating immune cells. The degree to which astrocytomas express stereotyped reactive programs versus adopting alternative transcriptional states remains an active area of investigation, with implications for immune checkpoint therapy response.

## Transcriptional Control Networks and Chromatin Organization

Astrocytoma cells exhibit marked alterations in transcriptional regulation compared to normal astrocytes, with multiple transcription factors driving both tumor maintenance and cellular plasticity. SATB2 (special AT-rich sequence binding protein 2) encodes a chromatin organizer that binds AT-rich DNA elements and nucleates chromatin loops controlling gene expression[49]. Originally described in post-mitotic neurons, SATB2 plays roles in neuronal differentiation and may influence developmental programs in tumor contexts[49]. TCF7L2 (transcription factor 7 like 2) and TCF7 represent LEF/TCF family members that mediate Wnt signaling by forming complexes with beta-catenin to activate target genes[43][45]. High TCF7 expression in glioblastomas correlates with poor prognosis, and TCF7-driven programs likely overlap substantially with Wnt pathway activation[45].

BCL6 (B-cell lymphoma 6), traditionally characterized in B cells, functions as a transcriptional repressor that silences differentiation-promoting genes[65]. The presence of BCL6 in astrocytoma gene expression programs may reflect maintained stemness or suppression of mature glial programs. The histone modifier HMGA2 (high mobility group A2) and its antisense transcript HMGA2-AS1 represent oncofetal genes reactivated in multiple cancer types[42]. HMGA2 functions as an architectural protein organizing chromatin higher-order structure and appears particularly important for supporting cancer stem cell properties. PRICKLE1 and PRICKLE2 represent negative regulators of Wnt-beta-catenin signaling[28], potentially providing feedback limitation on Wnt pathway activation. These transcriptional regulators collectively orchestrate the gene expression landscape distinguishing astrocytomas from normal astrocytes.

## Metabolic Reprogramming and Bioenergetic Adaptations

Glioblastomas and astrocytomas undergo substantial metabolic reprogramming to support rapid proliferation and adaptation to hypoxic microenvironments[53][56]. Multiple genes within the input list encode enzymes and transporters mediating glucose and lipid metabolism. The acetyl-CoA synthetase ACSS3 activates acetate to acetyl-CoA, feeding both oxidative metabolism and acetyl-CoA-dependent protein acetylation processes that regulate gene expression and protein function[15]. GFPT2 (glutamine-fructose-6-phosphate aminotransferase 2) catalyzes the initial committed step of hexosamine biosynthesis, generating UDP-N-acetylglucosamine for glycoprotein synthesis and cellular signaling[15].

The glucose transporter SLC4A7, while classically involved in bicarbonate transport, may participate in coupled glucose and pH homeostasis relevant to tumor cell survival in nutrient-limited microenvironments[15]. The solute carrier proteins and transporters within the list (SLC44A5, SLC-related genes) enable uptake of essential amino acids and other nutrients required for anabolic metabolism. Mitochondrial genes MT-CO2, MT-ATP6, MT-CYB, and MT-CO3 encode critical components of oxidative phosphorylation and ATP synthesis[27][30], essential for supporting tumor cell viability particularly in well-oxygenated tumor regions. The expression of these mitochondrial genes varies substantially within astrocytomas, reflecting intratumoral metabolic heterogeneity and differential reliance on oxidative versus glycolytic metabolism.

Lipid metabolism also appears represented through OSBPL3 and OSBPL2 (oxysterol binding protein-like proteins), which regulate intracellular sterol and lipid transport essential for membrane biogenesis in rapidly dividing cells[15]. These metabolic enzymes collectively support the anabolic demands of tumor growth while enabling adaptation to variable microenvironmental conditions. The metabolic program becomes particularly critical in hypoxic tumor regions where oxidative metabolism becomes limited and glycolytic and biosynthetic pathways dominate.

## Long Noncoding RNAs and Regulatory RNA Networks

An expanding literature demonstrates that long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) play central roles in cancer biology by regulating mRNA stability, protein-RNA interactions, and chromatin structure[14]. Several genes within the input list encode or are associated with lncRNAs relevant to astrocytoma biology. NEAT1 (nuclear enriched abundant transcript 1) functions as a structural component of paraspeckle nuclear bodies that regulate alternative splicing and mRNA processing[14]. Dysregulation of NEAT1 has been implicated in various cancers and may influence astrocytoma gene expression patterns through effects on mRNA fate.

HMGA2-AS1 represents an antisense transcript to the HMGA2 locus, with potential roles in regulating HMGA2 stability or function[15]. Multiple annotated antisense and intronic lncRNAs including AC007098.1, AC016745.1, AC090791.1, AC110058.1, AL354740.1, AL596087.2, and LINC genes (LINC01138, LINC02821, LINC02742) populate the input list. While specific functions for each lncRNA remain under investigation, these transcripts likely participate in post-transcriptional regulation, chromatin organization, and signaling functions relevant to astrocytoma biology. MIR4435-2HG and MIR222HG represent miRNA host genes, with the encoded miRNAs potentially regulating target mRNAs within tumor cells and the tumor microenvironment. The regulatory RNA program likely couples with traditional transcriptional control to establish and maintain the astrocytoma phenotype.

## Hypoxia-Responsive Gene Expression and Stress Adaptation

Astrocytomas exhibit pronounced intratumoral hypoxia despite active neoangiogenesis, reflecting both rapid tumor growth outpacing vascular supply and aberrant vascular architecture[53][56]. Hypoxia-inducible transcription factors (HIF1alpha and HIF2alpha, not explicitly in list but regulating many listed genes) drive transcriptional programs enabling metabolic adaptation and stress response. The gene C6ORF141 and related poorly characterized open reading frames may participate in hypoxia-responsive processes. The gene GFPT2, while primarily characterized for hexosamine biosynthesis, may be upregulated under hypoxic stress[15]. Complement component 5a (C5a) production in hypoxic glioblastomas promotes invasion and stemness through actions on C5a receptors expressed by tumor and stromal cells[56].

The adenosine nucleoside metabolism gene NT5E (CD73) represents a hypoxia-responsive gene regulating the conversion of AMP to adenosine, which functions as an immunosuppressive molecule in the tumor microenvironment. The CFLAR (caspase-8 and FADD-like apoptosis regulator) protein suppresses death receptor signaling, promoting cell survival during nutrient stress. These hypoxia-responsive genes collectively enable astrocytomas to persist and proliferate despite microenvironmental stress. The upregulation of HIF-target genes under hypoxia likely includes many of the genes encoded by the input list, though direct demonstration of hypoxic regulation for each gene remains incomplete.

## Cell Cycle Control and Proliferation Regulation

Astrocytomas demonstrate constitutive proliferation reflecting disruption of normal cell cycle checkpoints and checkpoint control mechanisms. The cyclin-dependent kinase CDK6 promotes cell cycle progression through G1/S checkpoint control, and upregulation of CDK6 or loss of its inhibitors (p16/CDKN2A, frequently deleted in IDH wild-type glioblastomas but not directly in input list) promotes proliferation[26][29]. The HMGA2 protein functions as an oncofetal regulator supporting proliferation through effects on transcriptional programs controlling cell cycle progression. The Wnt signaling pathway (mediated through TCF7, TCF7L2, and beta-catenin) promotes proliferation through effects on c-MYC and other proliferation-associated genes.

The negative regulator PRICKLE1 suppresses proliferation through effects on Wnt signaling[28], suggesting that reduced PRICKLE1 expression might contribute to proliferation in astrocytomas. The kinase cascade PTPN14 and related phosphatases provide feedback limitation on proliferation signals, with loss or downregulation of these phosphatases potentially contributing to constitutive proliferation. These proliferation-supporting genes collectively drive the rapid growth characteristic of high-grade astrocytomas, particularly IDH wild-type glioblastomas.

## Immune Modulation and Microenvironment Sculpting

Astrocytomas extensively remodel their microenvironment through secretion of immune-modulating cytokines and chemokines that shape infiltration of immune cells[10][22][56]. The chemokine CCL2 (monocyte chemoattractant protein 1) promotes recruitment and activation of monocytes and macrophages into the tumor microenvironment. CXCL14 represents another chemokine with broader immune modulatory functions. The interleukin IL1B and IL1R1 mediate local inflammatory signaling with context-dependent effects on tumor progression[36]. The cytokine LIF (leukemia inhibitory factor) suppresses differentiation and supports stemness in various cancer contexts[64][67].

The TNF-alpha pathway (TNF gene not in list but TNF receptor signaling involving multiple listed genes) promotes inflammation and can paradoxically support tumor progression through NFkappaB signaling. The complement pathway genes represented in the list (particularly through C5aR1 and C5a signaling) provide additional immune sculpting capacity, with C5a promoting myeloid infiltration and T cell suppression[56]. The lymphangiogenic growth factor VEGF-D and related factors promote lymphatic remodeling, potentially facilitating metastatic dissemination[21]. These immune modulatory genes collectively establish an immunosuppressive microenvironment that protects tumor cells from immune attack while supporting a pro-tumor immune cell infiltrate.

## Neuronal and Synaptic Programs in Astrocytomas

An intriguing finding in astrocytoma biology involves the upregulation of genes normally associated with neuronal functions, suggesting that tumor cells partially recapitulate aspects of neuronal differentiation programs[53][57]. The growth-associated protein GAP43, calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase CAMK2D, and synaptosomal proteins (SYT genes potentially including SYTL5) appear in multiple astrocytoma studies[15]. The neuropeptide Y precursor gene NPY and related neuropeptide processing may reflect partial activation of neurosecretory pathways. The neurotrophic factor receptor NTR-related genes and neurotrophic signaling cascades may support survival signaling in tumor cells.

The axis of neuronal program activation becomes particularly evident in spatial transcriptomic studies showing that subsets of tumor cells express mature neuronal markers including MAP1B and synaptic proteins[53]. This finding suggests either that astrocytomas derive from multipotent progenitors capable of neuronal differentiation or that differentiated neurons become incorporated into tumors through some mechanism of transdifferentiation or cell fusion. The functional significance of neuronal program activation in astrocytomas remains unclear but may provide metabolic or survival advantages in specific microenvironments. The genes NPTX2 (neuronal pentraxin 2) and other synaptically-regulated molecules may enable neuron-like signaling properties that influence local circuit function and potentially facilitate perineural invasion or interaction with remnant host neurons.

## Conclusion: Integrating Gene Programs into Astrocytoma Pathobiology

The 169 genes within the input list encode products participating in coordinated programs driving astrocytoma initiation, progression, invasion, and adaptation to microenvironmental stress. These programs include extracellular matrix remodeling enabling invasion, signal transduction cascades supporting proliferation and survival, cytoskeletal reorganization permitting cell motility, adhesive interactions governing cellular organization and communication, reactive astrocyte-like programs coupling to immune modulation, transcriptional control networks establishing tumor identity, metabolic reprogramming supporting rapid growth, regulatory RNA networks fine-tuning gene expression, hypoxia-responsive adaptations enabling survival in nutrient-poor regions, cell cycle control sustaining proliferation, immune sculpting establishing immunosuppressive microenvironments, and partial recapitulation of neuronal programs with unclear but potentially important functional consequences.

The integration of these programs occurs through multiple interconnected mechanisms. Receptor tyrosine kinase signaling (KDR, NRP1/NRP2, EFNB2) converges with integrin signaling (ITGA3, ITGAV, PTK2B) to coordinately drive migration through effects on both transcriptional and post-translational control of cytoskeletal proteins (MAP1B, GAP43, DNMBP, KALRN). Transcriptional programs (SATB2, TCF7L2, BCL6, HMGA2) maintain expression of this invasive phenotype while simultaneously supporting metabolic adaptations (ACSS3, GFPT2) and stress responses (C5a, adenosine pathways). The reactive astrocyte-like program (CHI3L1, SERPINE1, IL1R1) sculpts immune infiltration while adhesive molecules (CDH2, CNTNAP3, NRCAM) organize tumor architecture. Finally, evidence for partial activation of neuronal/synaptic programs (GAP43, CAMK2D, MAP1B) suggests profound plasticity in astrocytoma cellular identity.

Understanding these programs at the level of individual gene function remains important, but equal emphasis must be placed on understanding the integrated network behavior. Therapeutic targeting of single pathway components has proven partially effective but insufficient in achieving durable remissions, reflecting the redundancy and plasticity built into these programs. Future therapeutic strategies may require simultaneous targeting of multiple integrated programs—for example, simultaneously blocking growth factor signaling, blocking adhesion-based survival signals, and disrupting the immunosuppressive microenvironment to achieve more complete tumor control.
